title: Fitting The World to Minds: Brain Basis of Sharing and Transmitting Representations of the Social World
descriptions: The "Fitting The World to Minds: Brain Basis of Sharing and Transmitting Representations of the Social World" grant proposal aims to develop a comprehensive neurocognitive model that elucidates how individuals maintain and communicate shared neural representations of the dynamic social world. The project addresses the challenges posed by conceptual and technical limitations in studying social information representation, as well as the use of simplistic social stimuli in experiments. Leveraging recent advances in brain signal analysis, the proposal adopts a novel approach by studying social interaction in naturalistic settings and measuring temporal synchronization of brain activity across individuals. The project utilizes innovative signal analysis methods, experimental techniques, and rapid magnetic resonance image acquisition to test hypotheses on selective synchronization of brain circuits during social interaction, association between cognitive task sets and synchronous brain activity, and the impact of intense emotional experiences on brain responses and information flow. The outcomes of this research are expected to enhance the understanding of brain dynamics in social interaction and potentially lead to a paradigm shift in social and cognitive neuroscience. This project represents a unique "Naturalistic neuroscience approach" that has the potential to significantly advance our knowledge in this field.
